name: The BCKW forest
intro: The BCKW system
consists of four independent operations:
<ul>
• B a b c = a (b c) — composition,
• C a b c = a c b — swapping,
• K a b = a — discarding, and
• W a b = a b b — duplication.
Those are sufficient to rewrite an arbitrary expression E in the form
F x where free variable x may or may not be present in E
but does not appear in F.
Such transformation is harder to formalize than the one for S and K,
but may be more convenient to perform for a human.
In order to do so, one needs to determine the last free variable to be extracted,
and then use B to pull it towards the root of the expression tree,
C to push it to the right, W to merge duplicates,
and K to discard unneeded variables.
Once a variable gets to the end, it is eliminated and the process repeats
until only constants are left.
There are often multiple paths to the desired form,
e.g. it may be feasible to lift a whole subtree and not just one variable.
But the technique always succeeds.

content.intro: Build the I combinator (yes, again) from B, C, K, and W.

content.name: A cup of T
intro: An expression f y x can be written as C f x y, and vice versa.
But what if f is missing and you just have y x
and want them in different order?
Perhaps you have to add something to C to pull it off...
Find an expression T such that T x y = y x.

content.name: The Turing bird
intro: I've seen at least 3 things denoted by U in the literature concerning combinators.
This time U means a function of 2 arguments: U a b = a (b b a).
Build it!

content.name: ADAC
intro: ADAC
stands for Allgemeiner Deutscher Automobil-Club, meaning General German Automobile Club.
It is an organization that provides road-side assistance, insurance, and generally promotion of
automobile use across Germany.
Build a d a c from a b c d.
